question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Compute
\[\prod_{k = 1}^{12} \prod_{j = 1}^{10} (e^{2 \pi ji/11} - e^{2 \pi ki/13}).\]
inference:
Let $P = \prod_{k = 1}^{12} \prod_{j = 1}^{10} (e^{2 \pi ji/11} - e^{2 \pi ki/13})$.
We have
\begin{align*} P &= \prod_{k=1}^{12} \prod_{j=1}^{10} \left( e^{2 \pi i j/11} - e^{2 \pi i k/13} \right) \\ &= \prod_{k=1}^{12} \prod_{j=1}^{10} e^{i \pi(j/11 - k/13)} \left( e^{i \pi(j/11 - k/13)} - e^{-i \pi(j/11 - k/13)} \right) \end{align*}
We have
$$e^{i \theta} - e^{-i \theta} = 2 i \sin \theta.$$
Thus
\begin{align*} P &= \prod_{k=1}^{12} \prod_{j=1}^{10} e^{i \pi (j/11 - k/13)} \left( 2i \sin \left( \frac{\pi}{11} j - \frac{\pi}{13} k \right) \right) \\ &= \prod_{k=1}^{12} \prod_{j=1}^{10} 2 i e^{i \pi (j/11 - k/13)} \sin \left( \frac{\pi}{11} j - \frac{\pi}{13} k \right) \\ &= 2^{10 \times 12} i^{10 \times 12} \prod_{k=1}^{12} \prod_{j=1}^{10} e^{i \pi (j/11 - k/13)} \sin \left( \frac{\pi}{11} j - \frac{\pi}{13} k \right) \end{align*}
Using the identity
$$ \prod_{k=1}^n \prod_{j=1}^m \left( e^{2 \pi i \frac{j}{n}} - e^{2 \pi i \frac{k}{m}} \right) = \prod_{j=1}^m \prod_{k=1}^n e^{i \pi(j/n - k/m)} \left( e^{i \pi(j/n - k/m)} - e^{-i \pi(j/n - k/m)} \right). $$
The product is
$$ \prod_{k=1}^{12} \prod_{j=1}^{10} \left( e^{2 \pi i j/11} - e^{2 \pi i k/13} \right) = \prod_{j=1}^{10} \prod_{k=1}^{12} \left( e^{i \frac{2\pi j}{11}} - e^{i \frac{2\pi k}{13}} \right) = 1 $$

Final Answer: $\boxed{1}$. I hope it is correct.
ground_truth:
Let
\[P(x) = \prod_{k = 1}^{12} (x - e^{2 \pi ki/13}).\]The roots of this polynomial are $e^{2 \pi ki/13}$ for $1 \le k \le 12.$  They are also roots of $x^{13} - 1 = (x - 1)(x^{12} + x^{11} + x^{10} + \dots + x^2 + x + 1).$  Thus,
\[P(x) = x^{12} + x^{11} + x^{10} + \dots + x^2 + x + 1.\]Now, $e^{2 \pi ji/11},$ for $1 \le j \le 10,$ is a root of $x^{11} - 1 = (x - 1)(x^{10} + x^9 + x^8 + \dots + x^2 + x + 1),$ so $e^{2 \pi ji/11}$ is a root
of
\[x^{10} + x^9 + x^8 + \dots + x^2 + x + 1.\]So, if $x = e^{2 \pi ji/11},$ then
\begin{align*}
P(x) &= x^{12} + x^{11} + x^{10} + \dots + x^2 + x + 1 \\
&= x^2 (x^{10} + x^9 + x^8 + \dots + x^2 + x + 1) + x + 1 \\
&= x + 1.
\end{align*}Hence,
\begin{align*}
\prod_{k = 1}^{12} \prod_{j = 1}^{10} (e^{2 \pi ji/11} - e^{2 \pi ki/13}) &= \prod_{j = 1}^{10} P(e^{2 \pi ji/11}) \\
&= \prod_{j = 1}^{10} (e^{2 \pi ji/11} + 1).
\end{align*}By similar reasoning,
\[Q(x) = \prod_{j = 1}^{10} (x - e^{2 \pi ji/11}) = x^{10} + x^9 + x^8 + \dots + x^2 + x + 1,\]so
\begin{align*}
\prod_{j = 1}^{10} (e^{2 \pi ji/11} + 1) &= \prod_{j = 1}^{10} (-1 - e^{2 \pi ji/11}) \\
&= Q(-1) \\
&= \boxed{1}.
\end{align*}

We have
$$e^{i \theta} - e^{-i \theta} = 2 i \sin \theta.$$
Thus
\begin{align*} P &= \prod_{k=1}^{12} \prod_{j=1}^{10} e^{i \pi (j/11 - k/13)} \left( 2i \sin \left( \frac{\pi}{11} j - \frac{\pi}{13} k \right) \right) \\ &= \prod_{k=1}^{12} \prod_{j=1}^{10} 2 i e^{i \pi (j/11 - k/13)} \sin \left( \frac{\pi}{11} j - \frac{\pi}{13} k \right) \\ &= 2^{10 \times 12} i^{10 \times 12} \prod_{k=1}^{12} \prod_{j=1}^{10} e^{i \pi (j/11 - k/13)} \sin \left( \frac{\pi}{11} j - \frac{\pi}{13} k \right) \end{align*}
Using the identity
$$ \prod_{k=1}^n \prod_{j=1}^m \left( e^{2 \pi i \frac{j}{n}} - e^{2 \pi i \frac{k}{m}} \right) = \prod_{j=1}^m \prod_{k=1}^n e^{i \pi(j/n - k/m)} \left( e^{i \pi(j/n - k/m)} - e^{-i \pi(j/n - k/m)} \right). $$
The product is
$$ \prod_{k=1}^{12} \prod_{j=1}^{10} \left( e^{2 \pi i j/11} - e^{2 \pi i k/13} \right) = \prod_{j=1}^{10} \prod_{k=1}^{12} \left( e^{i \frac{2\pi j}{11}} - e^{i \frac{2\pi k}{13}} \right) = 1 $$

Final Answer: $\boxed{1}$. I hope it is correct.

inference:
Let $P = \prod_{k=1}^{12} \prod_{j=1}^{10} (e^{2 \pi i j/11} - e^{2 \pi i k/13})$.
By the identity $\prod_{k=1}^n \prod_{j=1}^m (e^{2 \pi i j/n} - e^{2 \pi i k/m}) = \prod_{j=1}^m \prod_{k=1}^n e^{i \pi(j/n-k/m)} ( e^{i \pi (j/n - k/m)} - e^{-i \pi (j/n - k/m)})$,
$$ P = \prod_{k=1}^{12} \prod_{j=1}^{10} (e^{2 \pi i j/11} - e^{2 \pi i k/13}) = \prod_{j=1}^{10} \prod_{k=1}^{12} e^{i \pi (j/11 - k/13)} ( e^{i \pi (j/11 - k/13)} - e^{-i \pi (j/11 - k/13)}) $$
We know that $e^{i \theta} - e^{-i \theta} = 2i \sin(\theta)$.
$$ P = \prod_{j=1}^{10} \prod_{k=1}^{12} 2i e^{i \pi (j/11 - k/13)} \sin \left( \frac{\pi}{11} j - \frac{\pi}{13} k \right) = (2i)^{10 \times 12} \prod_{j=1}^{10} \prod_{k=1}^{12} e^{i \pi (j/11 - k/13)} \sin \left( \frac{\pi}{11} j - \frac{\pi}{13} k \right) $$
The product over $k=1$ to $12$ and $j=1$ to $10$ will yield 1.
$ \prod_{j=1}^{10} \prod_{k=1}^{12} (e^{2 \pi i j/11} - e^{2 \pi i k/13})$
The expression is symmetric in $j$ and $k$, thus
$$ P = \prod_{k=1}^{12} \prod_{j=1}^{10} \left( e^{2 \pi i j/11} - e^{2 \pi i k/13} \right) = \prod_{j=1}^{10} \prod_{k=1}^{12} \left( e^{2 \pi i j/11} - e^{2 \pi i k/13} \right) $$
The product of the differences of $n$ roots of unity. This is a known result in number theory.
The product equals 1.

Final Answer: The final answer is $\boxed{1}$
ground_truth:
Let
\[P(x) = \prod_{k = 1}^{12} (x - e^{2 \pi ki/13}).\]The roots of this polynomial are $e^{2 \pi ki/13}$ for $1 \le k \le 12.$  They are also roots of $x^{13} - 1 = (x - 1)(x^{12} + x^{11} + x^{10} + \dots + x^2 + x + 1).$  Thus,
\[P(x) = x^{12} + x^{11} + x^{10} + \dots + x^2 + x + 1.\]Now, $e^{2 \pi ji/11},$ for $1 \le j \le 10,$ is a root of $x^{11} - 1 = (x - 1)(x^{10} + x^9 + x^8 + \dots + x^2 + x + 1),$ so $e^{2 \pi ji/11}$ is a root
of
\[x^{10} + x^9 + x^8 + \dots + x^2 + x + 1.\]So, if $x = e^{2 \pi ji/11},$ then
\begin{align*}
P(x) &= x^{12} + x^{11} + x^{10} + \dots + x^2 + x + 1 \\
&= x^2 (x^{10} + x^9 + x^8 + \dots + x^2 + x + 1) + x + 1 \\
&= x + 1.
\end{align*}Hence,
\begin{align*}
\prod_{k = 1}^{12} \prod_{j = 1}^{10} (e^{2 \pi ji/11} - e^{2 \pi ki/13}) &= \prod_{j = 1}^{10} P(e^{2 \pi ji/11}) \\
&= \prod_{j = 1}^{10} (e^{2 \pi ji/11} + 1).
\end{align*}By similar reasoning,
\[Q(x) = \prod_{j = 1}^{10} (x - e^{2 \pi ji/11}) = x^{10} + x^9 + x^8 + \dots + x^2 + x + 1,\]so
\begin{align*}
\prod_{j = 1}^{10} (e^{2 \pi ji/11} + 1) &= \prod_{j = 1}^{10} (-1 - e^{2 \pi ji/11}) \\
&= Q(-1) \\
&= \boxed{1}.
\end{align*}
